author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Wonder Woman and Her Evolving Look
description: She remained steadfast in her decades-long fight for justice, but her costumes ranged from a golden-eagle emblem and skirt to a W logo breastplate and leggings.
content: In a trailer for “Wonder Woman 1984,” the title hero is clad in golden armor. That image had fans’ pulses racing because in comic books, the metallic suit is what the heroine dons for major battles. Wonder Woman, who was introduced in 1941, is part of DC’s Holy Trinity of heroes that includes Superman, who debuted in 1938, and Batman, who premiered in 1939. Like the outfits of her fellow heroes, Wonder Woman’s costume has evolved over time and even occasionally received a complete makeover. Here are some notable looks from the Amazing Amazon over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden Admonishes Trump Administration Over ‘Obstruction’
description: “Right now, we just aren’t getting all the information that we need from the outgoing administration in key national security areas,” the president-elect said.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Monday that his transition team had faced “obstruction” from the Defense Department, raising new concerns about the Trump administration’s cooperation with transition officials with just over three weeks until Inauguration Day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Like Looking Into a Mirror’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: My 14-year-old, Vedant, dwells in a dungeon (i.e. basement) under my bedroom. Through the muffled cadence of his voice, I deduce if he’s in virtual school or playing an online game. Thrice a day, he comes up for air, asking, “What’s there to eat?” We used to talk a lot on our car rides, about life and feelings. Now we have nowhere to go. For the holidays, I make him my sous chef. Slicing a butternut squash, my knife slips. He takes my bleeding finger in his hand and blows a kiss. Food an excuse, we talk about feelings again. — Yogyata Singh Davé
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: Runners’ Post-Pandemic Dreams
description: We asked what you’re hoping to do when it’s safe again. Here’s what several runners told us.
content: This was a different and difficult year for running, with the Olympics delayed, major marathons and races canceled, and even group runs largely off the table.We asked readers what they dream about doing as soon as it’s safe to gather again. Here’s what some of our running readers had to say. (Responses have been edited and condensed.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Weeks-Old Statue of Breonna Taylor Is Battered in Oakland, Calif.
description: The vandalism of the ceramic sculpture of Ms. Taylor near City Hall is under investigation, the police said.
content: The clay took several months for a Bay Area sculptor to shape with his hands into a likeness of Breonna Taylor, which he finished with a dark brown satin glaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: A New Year’s Treat to Close Out a Difficult Year
description: Dorie Greenspan is baking this layer cake, a cousin to gingerbread with plenty of frosting, hoping it will make 2021 a bit sweeter.
content: I knew that New Year’s Eve 2020 would be different; still, I never thought I would be planning to bake a cake. None of my last 20 or so New Year’s Eve dinners ever ended with a layer cake that involved molasses and cream cheese. But then, those dinners were in Paris. And for almost all of them, I cooked for more people than I could comfortably squeeze around our table — one year I had to buy 20 folding chairs and set up dishes on every flat surface in the apartment. No matter how many we were, I always had to use every outdoor ledge, sill and flower box to hold wine. And I always crossed my fingers and hoped that Bacchus would keep the bottles from tumbling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: My Daughter, TikTok Warrior
description: How my family found an unlikely bridge across the divide created by cancer.
content: On the fourth floor at Children’s National Medical Center in Washington, D.C., one of the women in Vitals calls my 11-year-old daughter “TikTok.” As in, “Hey, TikTok, what’s happening today?” Then she asks her to get on the scale. It is disarmingly kind, this casual nod to life beyond oncology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mady Camara and Ruth Maclean
title: Arrest of Cameraman in Ethiopia Signals Wider Crackdown
description: The government of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has stepped up the arrests of journalists since going to war in the country’s northern region of Tigray.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — The arrest of a cameraman working for the news agency Reuters in the Ethiopian capital last week shows how press freedom has eroded in a country now engaged in a war with one of its own states, according to an international media watchdog group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Another Top U.S. Tennis Tournament Is Postponed Because of the Coronavirus
description: The BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif., hopes to move to later in the year.
content: One of the most important American tennis tournaments will not take place in the United States this spring because the country has not been able to bring the coronavirus under control, tennis officials announced Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Lost in 2020: Epic Shakespeare, and the Theater That Planned It
description: Brave Spirits Theater expected to mount an ambitious cycle of eight history plays. Instead it became yet another victim of the pandemic.
content: I’ve written several versions of this story. First it was supposed to be an account of a small theater company’s ambitious stage project, then a story about that interrupted project and the company’s plan to regroup because of the pandemic. Now it’s an elegy for a small theater that the coronavirus shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Thousands Await Word in Prison as Trump Frees a Privileged Few
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 29, 2020.
content: “It’s kind of like a competition instead of a legal procedure. It’s a crony system.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Vaccinations have begun at the nursing home hit by the first U.S. virus cluster.
description: A nurse at the suburban Seattle nursing home that was ravaged by the first U.S. cluster of coronavirus cases sat down beside a visiting pharmacist on Monday, pulled up her blue shirtsleeve and received the first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine administered at the facility.
content: A nurse at the suburban Seattle nursing home that was ravaged by the first U.S. cluster of coronavirus cases sat down beside a visiting pharmacist on Monday, pulled up her blue shirtsleeve and received the first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine administered at the facility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: The Double Life of Franco A.
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Today, The Times’s Berlin bureau chief, Katrin Bennhold, tells the story of a far-right German terrorism suspect with a refugee alias.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Sex to Murder
description: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: MARSHLANDS, by André Gide. Translated by Damion Searls. (NYRB Classics, paper, $14.95.) This witty metafiction, first published in 1895 and freshly translated by Searls, mocks literary airs: Its hero claims to be writing a novel (called “Marshlands”) but spends all day regaling acquaintances instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Tisserand
title: Animation’s Early Days: Artists, Hucksters, Talking Mice and Pigs
description: Reid Mitenbuler’s “Wild Minds” details wild times, when cartoonists pictured sex and death as well as cute animals.
content: WILD MINDSThe Artists and Rivalries That Inspired the Golden Age of AnimationBy Reid Mitenbuler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Egypt Court Sentences Ex-Student to 3 Years in #MeToo Case
description: The court convicted Ahmed Bassam Zaki, a former student at American University in Cairo, of blackmailing and sexually harassing two women, in a case that has fueled the country’s #MeToo movement.
content: CAIRO (AP) — An Egyptian court on Tuesday convicted a former student at an elite university of sexual misconduct charges and sentenced him to three years in prison, the first conviction in a case that has fueled the #MeToo movement in the Arab world’s most populous country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $11.4 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Take a Culinary Road Trip With ‘The Roads to Rome’
description: It explores the foods along the Via Appia, the ancient Roman road.
content: Jarrett Wrisley, who lived in Italy, and Paolo Vitaletti, who is from Falcognano, near Rome, and is a chef and partner at Appia, an Italian restaurant in Bangkok, have written a compelling new travel and recipe book. The result of several trips to Italy, it explores the foods that punctuate the Via Appia, the ancient Roman road. They take the reader from Emilia-Romagna south through Tuscany, Umbria, Lazio and down to Campania and Puglia, then back to Rome. Along the way, they summon encounters with local food producers and discuss the often rustic tastes of these regions with a penchant for vegetables, sturdy cheeses and offal. A raw zucchini salad with Parmigiano-Reggiano and mint, and seafood meatballs in Bari were two of the recipes I’ll keep, along with everything they say about anchovies. For making cacio e pepe and carbonara, there’s a clever method using a bowl suspended over the pasta pot. Their all’Amatriciana, profiled on a visit to Amatrice before it was destroyed by the 2016 earthquake, brought back memories. The photographs are beautiful, but those that do not illustrate recipes lack helpful captions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A New Way to Mourn: An Update
description: A funeral, punctuated with technical difficulties and expressions of deep love, reveals the new rituals we are creating during the coronavirus crisis.
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes from this year and checking in on what has happened since the stories first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah B. Solomon
title: Treasury will begin sending the $600 stimulus checks.
description: While Congress continues to spar over whether to increase the size of stimulus payments to $2,000, the Treasury Department on Tuesday said it would begin depositing $600 checks into Americans’ bank accounts as early as Tuesday evening.
content: While Congress continues to spar over whether to increase the size of stimulus payments to $2,000, the Treasury Department on Tuesday said it would begin depositing $600 checks into Americans’ bank accounts as early as Tuesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Joe Orovic
title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Central Croatia
description: At least seven people were reported killed and dozens injured. The quake, with a preliminary magnitude of 6.4, was the second in the area in 24 hours and tremors were reported across the Balkans.
content: At least seven people were killed, dozens were wounded and several towns in central Croatia were left in ruins after a powerful 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck on Tuesday, according to the U.S. Geological Survey and Croatian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing 737 Max Resumes Flying U.S. Passengers After 2-Year Halt
description: American Airlines used the plane, which was grounded in March 2019 after two fatal crashes, on a flight from Miami to New York.
content: Boeing’s troubled 737 Max plane returned to American skies on Tuesday, carrying paying passengers in the United States for the first time in almost two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Surprise Ending for Publishers: In 2020, Business Was Good
description: With people stuck at home and so many other activities shut down, a lot of reading — or at least a lot of book buying — happened this year.
content: Like everybody else, book publishers will be happy to see the end of 2020. But for many of them, the year has brought some positive news, which has been as welcome as it was surprising: Business has been good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Fisher and Kirk Semple
title: Hit Hard by the Pandemic, Mexico’s Drug Cartels Tweaked Their Playbook
description: The brutal cartels, like legitimate companies, struggled as governments imposed border closures and lockdowns, and had to get creative.
content: CULIACÁN, Mexico — Like a lot of businesses, the Sinaloa Cartel was knocked back on its heels as the coronavirus swept the globe and travel ground to a near halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jorge Arangure Jr
title: ‘Whole System in Crisis’: A Short Covid History in My Notebook
description: In March, a Metro desk editor began logging daily plans and ideas for covering the pandemic in New York. Looking back through those early notes now brings a mix of pride and pain.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: Life Without Amazon (Well, Almost)
description: For concerned customers, avoiding one of the world’s largest retailers and web service providers is proving harder than expected.
content: Blaze, a 24-year-old cashier living in Washington, D.C., doesn’t order from Amazon.com or shop at Whole Foods. He doesn’t watch movies or shows on Prime Video. He doesn’t own a Ring or a Kindle. And he doesn’t use Audible, Twitch or Zappos. He’s about as close as one can get to abstaining from Amazon entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A terrorism suspect, disguised as a refugee.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Another Arrest, and Jail Time, Due to a Bad Facial Recognition Match
description: A New Jersey man was accused of shoplifting and trying to hit an officer with a car. He is the third known Black man to be wrongfully arrested based on face recognition.
content: In February 2019, Nijeer Parks was accused of shoplifting candy and trying to hit a police officer with a car at a Hampton Inn in Woodbridge, N.J. The police had identified him using facial recognition software, even though he was 30 miles away at the time of the incident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Night of the Kings’ Review: Telling Tales to a Captive Audience
description: Ancient tradition fuses with modern struggles in a prison in Ivory Coast.
content: As the new arrival at a violent prison, the young man at the center of “Night of the Kings” faces a tough crowd. He’s assigned the ceremonial duty of telling stories all night, while the convicts’ ailing capo, Blackbeard, fends off succession plots. Philippe Lacôte’s restless film — a rare United States release from Ivory Coast — braids together its struggles for survival to suggest an entire country fighting to emerge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gonzalez
title: What We Saw This Year: Grief, Love and Stirrings of Hope
description: In a season of expectation, looking for respite and meaning.
content: This has been the year of the endless Advent. Whether staying safe at home with family, or venturing outdoors masked and socially distanced, we found ourselves waiting: for the coronavirus vaccine, a stimulus check or just a sign of hope — which may be eternal but has proved elusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: This Year, Try Downsizing Your Resolutions
description: 2020 was a rough one. Here’s how to make goals for 2021 that feel both satisfying and doable.
content: After the unpredictable, torrid year we’ve had, the idea of making New Year’s resolutions for 2021 might seem a tad overwhelming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Ulay, on His Own Terms
description: The performance artist, who died in March, was eclipsed by his former collaborator and lover, Marina Abramovic. But he also produced powerful work without her, as an exhibition in Amsterdam shows.
content: AMSTERDAM — Many know Ulay as the man who walked into Marina Abramovic’s performance “The Artist is Present” at the Museum of Modern Art a decade ago, and brought her to tears. That two-minute encounter between the former collaborators and lovers during her three-month sit-in at the New York museum has been viewed more than 18 million times on YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: How the Pandemic Has Been Devastating for Children From Low-Income Families
description: In communities struggling with poverty and gun violence, the coronavirus has only inflamed the difficulties that many families already were enduring.
content: Since the coronavirus arrived in her neighborhood in Southeast Washington, D.C., this past spring, 11-year-old Grenderline Etheridge has burst into tears many times for reasons she cannot explain. She has crawled into bed with her mother, something she had not done for a very long time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Steve Cavendish and Jamie McGee
title: A Tornado, a Pandemic and Now a Bombing: ‘Nashville Strong’ Is Tested
description: In 2020, the city has weathered a tornado’s devastation and the rippling consequences of the coronavirus pandemic. Then, a bewildering and unsettling attack made a tough year tougher.
content: NASHVILLE — Nashville did not need another test of its grit. Over the years, the city was strong after the Cumberland River surged beyond its banks, and it clawed its way back from tornadoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: Legal Abortion, Once a Long Shot in Catholic Argentina, Now Within Reach
description: A bill before the Senate would make abortion legal in the predominantly Catholic nation, the homeland of Pope Francis. Its approval likely would have significant effect across Latin America.
content: BUENOS AIRES — A vote to legalize abortion in Argentina was balanced on a knife’s edge Tuesday as the Senate debated a bill that would make this largely Catholic nation, homeland of Pope Francis, the largest in Latin America to take that step.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Co-ops in Spain’s Basque Region Soften Capitalism’s Rough Edges
description: A group of worker-owned businesses may present an alternative model to economies dominated by the interests of shareholders.
content: If the Erreka Group operated like most businesses, the pandemic would have delivered a traumatic blow to its workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Is Dairy Farming Cruel to Cows?
description: A small group of animal welfare scientists is seeking answers to that question. Facing a growing anti-dairy movement, many farmers are altering their practices.
content: SCHODACK LANDING, N.Y. — The 1,500 Jersey cows that Nathan Chittenden and his family raise in upstate New York seem to lead carefree lives. They spend their days lolling around inside well-ventilated barns and eating their fill from troughs. Three times a day, they file into the milking parlor, where computer-calibrated vacuums drain several gallons of warm milk from their udders, a process that lasts about as long as a recitation of “The Farmer in the Dell.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Boston Removes Statue of Formerly Enslaved Man Kneeling Before Lincoln
description: Officials voted unanimously to remove “Emancipation Group” in June, after a widespread petition and hours of debate.
content: A statue depicting a formerly enslaved man kneeling before President Abraham Lincoln was taken down from a Boston park on Tuesday after officials this summer voted unanimously for its removal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 60 of Our Favorite Teaching and Learning Resources From 2020
description: After looking back at everything we published this year, we compiled this list by culling from the posts with the most views, the most comments — or just the most love from our staff.
content: When you experience an unforgiving year like 2020, it’s tempting to want to hurry it out the door without saying goodbye. But before the year ends, we want to step back to take stock of the past 12 months at The Learning Network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Nursing Home Patients Are Dying of Loneliness
description: As the vaccine rolls out in nursing homes, more visits should be allowed.
content: When she had the routine of home, Angie Sinopoli was the talkative matriarch of a large Italian family who heaped praise on her children and grandchildren, even as her memory faded. Her youngest son, Steven, came by her house and cooked her dinner nearly every night. But after a couple of falls and bouts in rehabilitation centers, she ended up in a Syracuse nursing home on March 10. Two days later, it stopped all visits to protect residents from the coronavirus. Mrs. Sinopoli hasn’t seen family in more than nine months. Her vocabulary has dwindled to about 20 words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Single Bone Rib-Eye Roast for Small Feasts
description: A block of rib-eye from Heritage Foods can serve four, or two with leftovers.
content: A standing rib roast is a celebratory choice for a crowd, but in this year of shrunken gatherings, you can go small. A gorgeous block of rib-eye with only a single, massive bone from Heritage Foods can serve four, or two with leftovers. The lush, tender beef raised in Texas is a cross between Akaushi, a Japanese Wagyu breed, and American Angus. Let it sit at room temperature for two hours, place it bone-side down in a cast-iron skillet or roasting pan and sear it at 475 degrees for 15 minutes, then reduce the heat to 350 until the internal temperature reaches 120. (It might take less time than you expect.) Let it rest out of the oven, tented with foil, for 20 minutes before carving. It will creep up to about 130 degrees for medium-rare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: Knocking on Two Million Doors in Georgia
description: Control of the Senate could hinge on Black voters — and on an ambitious effort to get them to the polls in the largest numbers ever for the Jan. 5 runoff elections.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: What 2020 Was Like for People in the Retail Industry
description: The industry employs millions, and the upheaval it experienced played out in the lives of many Americans.
content: The retail industry was in the midst of a transformation before 2020. But the onset of the pandemic accelerated that change, fundamentally reordering how and where people shop, and rippling across the broader economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: U.S. Diet Guidelines Sidestep Scientific Advice to Cut Sugar and Alcohol
description: The government’s new nutritional recommendations arrive amid a pandemic that has taken a huge toll on American health.
content: Rejecting the advice of its scientific advisers, the federal government has released new dietary recommendations that sound a familiar nutritional refrain, advising Americans to “make every bite count” but dismissing experts’ specific recommendations to set new low targets for consumption of sugar and alcoholic beverages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Stay-at-Home Orders Set to Continue Amid ‘Surge on Top of a Surge’
description: Tuesday: The announcement extending the orders could come today. Also: Vaccine updates, and a Southern California storm.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Violent Year in New York and Across U.S. as Pandemic Fuels Crime Spike
description: A time without precedent saw huge increases in homicides and shootings in the city as some other types of crime plummeted.
content: The first disaster in a year of perpetual crises hit the New York Police Department in March, when the virus tore through the force, killing dozens and sickening entire detective squads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Source for Alcohol-Free Libations
description: Chris Becker, a former technology consultant, has about 170 nonalcoholic beers, wines and spirits on his website, Better Rhodes.
content: New alcohol-free libations are flooding the market. There is a demand, and it’s likely to increase in the short term as more people abstain during “Dry January.” But Chris Becker, a former technology consultant who doesn’t drink, has the long term in mind. He started a website, Better Rhodes, six months ago to meet what he sees as a growing market for nonalcoholic beers, wines and spirits, with more than 170 of them on the website. He said he has tried them all, but does not love them all. In his view, England has done the most with the category. “They’re way ahead of us, along with Australia, New Zealand and Canada,” he said. The widest selection is in gins, where the use of botanicals adds character, but he recommends them for mixed drinks, not in a martini. As for wines, he finds the best results in sparklers. A new one, Thomson & Scott’s Noughty from England ($19.99 for 750 milliliters), made from carbonated de-alcoholized chardonnay, nicely passes muster, especially when served with a nibble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seema Jayachandran
title: Financial Rewards for College Students Could Help Curb the Pandemic
description: A new study suggests ways of structuring payments to persuade even impulsive students to behave more cautiously.
content: With a dangerous winter ahead, containing the pandemic is crucial. One innovation worth trying in the months before vaccinations are widespread is to pay college students to be careful and remain free of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Britain Mourns a Cherished Education Exchange Program Ended by Brexit
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has vowed to replace the E.U.-wide Erasmus program with a national version, but former participants and university officials say the decision is shortsighted.
content: After his university in Scotland shut down in the spring because of the coronavirus, forcing him to study online from home, Jack Boag kept up his spirits by dreaming of what awaited him in the coming academic year: a semester abroad at the University of Amsterdam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Lawrence
title: Deb Haaland Is Our Hero. Here Is a Warning for Her.
description: Her nomination as secretary of the interior is historic, but as the first Native cabinet member, she would have to strike a delicate balance.
content: Within minutes of the announcement that President-elect Joe Biden had nominated Representative Deb Haaland of New Mexico as interior secretary, Native social media was celebrating. People in our community who have met Ms. Haaland began posting photos of her at Native events throughout Indian Country; one of my friends wrote, “Our auntie has done it!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: In ‘Beginners,’ a Writer Takes Up Chess and Surfing and Singing and Juggling and …
description: In his new book, Tom Vanderbilt says that our culture is so caught up in work and ambition that “we’re afraid of being just OK at things.”
content: Not far into “Beginners,” Tom Vanderbilt’s tribute to the life-changing magic of learning new skills, he describes taking his young daughter snowboarding. At the time, Vanderbilt was nearing 50; he decided to approach the activity with an open mind, freed from all expectation, even if he was old enough to know what the risks were. “I had no goals other than avoiding the hospital,” he writes, after referring to the novelist Norman Rush’s comparison of being in love to going into an undiscovered room. “I just wanted to enter a new ‘room.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: I Got Vaccinated. But the Shot Won’t Save My Dying Patients.
description: The selfies of health care workers getting vaccines can’t cure infections, but they may provide hope where supplies are sparse.
content: I barely even feel the needle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Jazz Onscreen, Depicted by Black Filmmakers at Last
description: “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,” “Sylvie’s Love” and “Soul” understand the music and its place in African-American life, a welcome break with Hollywood history.
content: Midway through “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,” the new Netflix drama based on August Wilson’s acclaimed stage play, the title character drifts into a monologue. “White folk don’t understand about the blues,” muses Rainey (Viola Davis), an innovator at the crossroads of blues and jazz with an unbending faith in her own expressive engine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: The coronavirus pandemic is “not necessarily the big one,” senior W.H.O. official says.
description: One of the World Health Organization’s senior officials warned on Monday that although the coronavirus pandemic has been “very severe,” it is “not necessarily the big one.”
content: One of the World Health Organization’s senior officials warned on Monday that although the coronavirus pandemic has been “very severe,” it is “not necessarily the big one.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal K. Katyal and John Monsky
title: Will Pence Do the Right Thing?
description: On Jan. 6, the vice president will preside as Congress counts the Electoral College’s votes. Let’s hope that he doesn’t do the unthinkable — and unconstitutional.
content: President Trump recently tweeted that “the ‘Justice’ Department and FBI have done nothing about the 2020 Presidential Election Voter Fraud,” followed by these more ominous lines: “Never give up. See everyone in D.C. on January 6th.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: What’s behind the E.U.-China investment agreement.
content: Beijing and Brussels are on the brink of an agreement to roll back restrictions on investment — a deal that has been seven years in the making. An announcement is expected this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Anna Schaverien
title: U.K. Virus Surge Surpasses Spring Peak as Lockdown Choices Loom
description: Facing record case and hospital numbers and a threatening variant strain, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is under pressure to shut schools and reimpose national restrictions, measures he once decried.
content: LONDON — About half of England is under the nation’s strictest lockdown measures, and people have been ordered to stay at home, but the coronavirus is still spreading at an alarming rate. Hospitals are treating more patients than at any time during the pandemic, the number of new infections has set a daily record, and there is a growing debate about allowing tens of thousands of students to return to classrooms after the holiday break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: You’re Infected With the Coronavirus. But How Infected?
description: Knowing the amount of virus carried in the body could help doctors predict the course of a patient’s illness.
content: As Covid-19 patients flood into hospitals nationwide, doctors are facing an impossible question. Which patients in the E.R. are more likely to deteriorate quickly, and which are most likely to fight off the virus and to recover?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: 2020 Was the Year Reaganism Died
description: The government promised to help — and it did.
content: Maybe it was the visuals that did it. It’s hard to know what aspects of reality make it into Donald Trump’s ever-shrinking bubble — and I’m happy to say that after Jan. 20 we won’t have to care about what goes on in his not-at-all beautiful mind — but it’s possible that he became aware of how he looked, playing golf as millions of desperate families lost their unemployment benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Black Homeowners Struggle to Get Insurers to Pay Claims
description: Black policyholders suspect discrimination as they deal with insurers, but it is impossible to prove because the insurers keep a lid on claims data.
content: When a pipe burst and flooded her home in 2018, Deonne Burgess knew the cleanup would be messy. What she didn’t expect was the scrutiny from State Farm, her home insurance provider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: With a Fortifying Soup, Haitians Share Their Pride in Independence
description: Even in the pandemic, they’ll celebrate Jan. 1 by doling out soup joumou, a dish defined by national and familial traditions.
content: To make soup joumou, the chef Wesly Jean Simon insists, you must first find the biggest pot in your kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz, Sarah Kliff and Quoctrung Bui
title: Obamacare, in Its First Big Test as Safety Net, Is Holding Up So Far
description: Job losses and the loss of insurance have typically gone hand in hand. This year, more Americans are staying covered.
content: In past recessions, the uninsured rate would surge. Now, for the first time, Americans are experiencing a recession with the Affordable Care Act in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian and Sophia June
title: The Things Our Bosses Said a Lot This Year
description: “You’re on mute” was said on 1,000 percent more calls between executives and investors in 2020 compared with 2019.
content: The coronavirus pandemic gave 2020 a new dictionary, and seemingly overnight, corporate America began speaking with a new language. In calls between executives and investors, there was a choice set of words and phrases that were used to describe the … unprecedented moment we all found ourselves living through. These are some of the phrases whose use skyrocketed this year, based on more than 20,000 corporate presentations that we analyzed with Sentieo, a research firm. (Surprisingly, executives swore just as much as last year.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: Remote schooling brings bigger losses for children still learning to speak English.
description: While the disruptions of 2020 have threatened learning loss for nearly all students across the country, the toll has been especially severe for students from immigrant homes where English is rarely if ever spoken.
content: While the disruptions of 2020 have threatened learning loss for nearly all students across the country, the toll has been especially severe for students from immigrant homes where English is rarely if ever spoken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: When ‘the American Way’ Met the Coronavirus
description: “If you want people to do the right thing you have to make it easy, and we’ve made it hard.”
content: The end of the year has been awkward for Gov. Andrew Cuomo. As he promotes his new, self-congratulatory book about navigating New York through its first coronavirus wave of in the spring, he is also battling a new surge of cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Herself’ Review: She Does It All
description: After fleeing her abusive husband, a woman figures out how to build a new home for herself and her daughters.
content: When a housing authority can’t provide the residence you need, why not build one yourself? The option obviously isn’t widely available. But a concatenation of circumstances, and the kindness of an old family friend, gives Sandra, a mom fleeing an abusive husband, the chance to do just that in “Herself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: How Poets Use Punctuation as a Superpower and a Secret Weapon
description: Just like line breaks and spacing decisions, typographical marks can shape how a reader hears the language.
content: A poet I know, reluctant to define what poetry can or can’t be, once suggested (somewhat facetiously) that a bag of dirt could be a poem if the poet deemed it so — calling to mind Marcel Duchamp’s readymades, the urinal turned into art by contextual/conceptual gesture alone. This got me thinking about what my own bare-minimum criteria for poetry might be. A bag of dirt in a gallery might be an installation, but I wasn’t quite willing to concede it could also be a poem — a poem must at least, on some level, I thought, be verbal. But was that quite right? What about Aram Saroyan’s famous visual poems, in particular the lowercase m with an extra hump — not even a word or part of a word; an unletter. Maybe poetry only requires typography — but doesn’t it also require sound, the sense that at least in theory you could hear the poem? I do feel I can “read” that long m — it has a sonic quality — and the Saroyan poem “lighght.” An ampersand alone on a page would represent a pronounceable word. But what about a parenthesis, or a semicolon?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Votes to Override Trump’s Veto of Military Bill
description: Republicans joined with Democrats to hand President Trump a rare legislative rebuke in the final days of his presidency. The bill will next be taken up by the Senate, where it is expected to pass.
content: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Monday to override President Trump’s veto of the annual military policy bill, mustering bipartisan support to enact the legislation over the president’s objections and handing him a rare legislative rebuke in the final days of his presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China Has All It Needs to Vaccinate Millions, Except Any Approved Vaccines
description: Across the country, local governments plan to inoculate 50 million people against the coronavirus by early next year. But the vaccines have not officially been approved.
content: Hospitals all over China have almost everything necessary for a mass coronavirus vaccination drive: Millions of doses. Refrigerators to store them. Health care workers trained to administer them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryant Rousseau
title: In 2020, We Were There: The Year’s 13 Most Popular Dispatches
description: Even challenged by extraordinary travel restrictions, our correspondents explored the world’s most compelling places, in 49 countries, although their journeys often became more local, and personal.
content: As in more typical years, our correspondents in 2020 sent dispatches from some of the world’s most far-flung, hard-to-access and downright dangerous places — from the deep chill of Siberia to the blazing heat of the Australian Outback; from the wilds of a jaguar preserve in Argentina to the inside of an armored personnel carrier crowded with French Foreign Legion troops in Mali.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Alan Feuer
title: How Richard Jewell’s Lawyer Became a Pro-Trump Conspiracy Theorist
description: The defamation lawyer L. Lin Wood has transformed into a fierce advocate for President Trump whose error-riddled lawsuits have promoted falsehoods about election fraud.
content: L. Lin Wood had a message from God to deliver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall Munroe
title: Will My Popcorn Explode?
description: The odds that all of your popcorn kernels will pop simultaneously aren’t zero. Maybe think instead of the multiple lotteries you’re more likely to win.
content: What would happen if, while I was popping popcorn, all the kernels popped at once? Should I be worried?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: K.C. Jones Never Got His Due in Boston. Race Played a Part.
description: Jones, who was Black and won eight championships as a player and two as a coach with the Boston Celtics, was underappreciated as one of the N.B.A.’s most successful coaches.
content: In early December 1990, K.C. Jones sat in a hotel suite overlooking the New Jersey Meadowlands before a game with the Nets, trying to explain why a coach who won 75 percent of his games and two N.B.A. titles with Boston, and who reached four league finals over five seasons, had been shoved upstairs into a toothless front-office position before ultimately departing his beloved Celtics to coach in Seattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: New Data Triples Russia’s Covid-19 Death Toll
description: The statistics agency said 230,000 more people died through November of this year than did in 2019, a hike attributable to the virus. Russia could jump to third among countries by number of Covid deaths.
content: MOSCOW — After months of questions over the true scale of the coronavirus pandemic in Russia and the efficacy of a Russian-developed vaccine, the state statistical agency in Moscow has announced new figures indicating that the death toll from Covid-19 is more than three times as high as officially reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Deep Within Relief Bill, Horse Racing Gets New Tools to Clean Up
description: A provision deep in the coronavirus stimulus package puts the United States Anti-Doping Agency in charge of regulating thoroughbred racing.
content: No one much liked the horse breeder and owner Arthur Hancock III in the spring of 1991 after he delivered what he now calls his “drugs-and-thugs speech” to the University of Arizona Symposium on Racing. He had spoken openly about thoroughbred racing’s dirty little secret: that too many of its horses were running on performance-enhancing drugs or were so doped up on anti-inflammatories and painkillers that they were running unnaturally fast and hurting themselves, often fatally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kareem Chehayeb
title: Bassam Saba, Renowned Proponent of Arabic Music, Dies at 62
description: A skilled multi-instrumentalist, Mr. Saba co-founded the New York Arabic Orchestra and directed Lebanon’s national conservatory of music. He died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León and Marie Fazio
title: Green Beret Charged in Shooting Spree Was Visiting Family, Prosecutor Says
description: A lawyer for Duke Webb said there was indication that the Green Beret, accused of killing three people at a Rockford, Ill., bowling alley, had PTSD.
content: The Army Green Beret charged with opening fire with two pistols at a bowling alley and restaurant in Rockford, Ill., over the weekend, killing three people and wounding three others, was on leave and visiting family members, the county prosecutor said on Monday. He declined to comment on a possible motive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Green Chutney From a Minneapolis Family Recipe
description: The sisters Sheilla and Yasameen Sajady turned the cilantro chutney made by their mother, Fatima, into a business.
content: Chutneys originated in India, but they have become a staple in many other countries. Afghanistan, which neighbors the subcontinent, is one of them. Several years ago, the sisters Sheilla and Yasameen Sajady turned the cilantro chutney made by their mother, Fatima, into a business, selling it locally in the Minneapolis area. (Their mother and father, Muchtar, immigrated from Afghanistan in the 1970s.) Now they have a website and are shipping jars of their tangy, green family recipe nationwide. It has endless uses on its own or as an ingredient. There is a hot version spiked with jalapeños and serranos, and a new vegan aioli for another excellent slather. Add some anchovies to that one. The name, Maazah, means flavor in Farsi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Get Cozy With a Chocolaty Champurrado Mix
description: La Monarca Bakery, a chain in the Los Angeles area, now sells its mix nationwide.
content: Rich and chocolaty champurrado, a Mexican beverage in the atole family, is easy to prepare with a mix from La Monarca Bakery, a chain in the Los Angeles area now selling it nationwide. Serve it with tamales or, for Epiphany, to sip with a circular rosca de reyes (king’s cake). It combines masa harina with cinnamon-scented chocolate and brown sugar to simmer in water or milk, and should be whisked to a froth. The bakery sells the mix with a molinillo, the traditional carved wooden Mexican stirring tool. Champurrado is usually a breakfast drink, but is inviting on a chilly late afternoon with a shot of mezcal. Mexican hot chocolate and coffee, Cafe de Olla, seasoned with spices, are also available. La Monarca’s name relates to the 1 percent of sales of all packaged items that it donates to Ecolife Conservation, a nonprofit working to protect the hordes of monarch butterflies that winter in central Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Employers are struggling to manage unused vacation days.
description: In a typical year, New York employees of the magazine publisher Condé Nast must use their vacation days before late December or lose them — a common policy across corporate America.
content: In a typical year, New York employees of the magazine publisher Condé Nast must use their vacation days before late December or lose them — a common policy across corporate America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Caviar and Champagne to Ring In 2021
description: Pick up a tin of Bulgarian osetra caviar and a bottle of Louis Roederer at Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s restaurant in the South Street Seaport.
content: Still looking for that tin of caviar and bottle of bubbly to bid good riddance to 2020? Pay attention to what Jean-Georges Vongerichten has on offer. A 50-gram (1.76-ounce) tin of Bulgarian osetra caviar with garnishes, enough for two, and a 750-milliliter bottle of Louis Roederer brut Champagne, for $128, make for a worthwhile package. But it’s only available for pickup at Mr. Vongerichten’s Fulton restaurant in the South Street Seaport on Dec. 30 or 31 from 3 to 7 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: Finding Love Without Alcohol
description: Going out for drinks has become a dating norm, but what if you’re sober?
content: Going out for a drink is a standard first date idea for many singles, but different rules apply if you’re sober.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: New York’s Real Climate Challenge: Fixing Its Aging Buildings
description: Nearly 70 percent of the city’s total carbon emissions come from buildings. A project to retrofit nine buildings with green technology is pioneering a new solution.
content: A plan to upgrade a cluster of nine unremarkable apartment buildings in Brooklyn typically would not merit a second look. But this isn’t a quick fix; the project, called Casa Pasiva, aims to be a new model for the sustainable transformation of the city’s housing stock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I Might Be Able to Jump the Vaccine Line. Should I?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on getting vaccinated through your husband’s job when, otherwise, you might have to wait a few more months — and more.
content: My husband works in an industry in which he is considered an essential worker. (Not health care.) I am covered under his employer’s health insurance. The arm of the organization that manages the health plan is, I just found out, negotiating with one of the pharmacy companies that will be involved to expedite the delivery of the coronavirus vaccine to the frontline workers. My husband is high up enough in the organization to ensure that I can get the vaccine along with the workers. Although we are both over 65, we have no underlying medical issues that put us at any special risk. Since the C.D.C. just established the guidelines for who has priority for getting the vaccine, can I ethically “jump the line”? Name Withheld, New York
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alden Wicker
title: Is This the End of the Mink Coat?
description: Mink may no longer become a legend most. But that doesn’t mean it’s disappearing entirely.
content: Perhaps no film better illustrates the role of the mink coat in American pop culture than “BUtterfield 8,” the 1960 film starring Elizabeth Taylor as a promiscuous socialite whose theft of a fur sets off a chain of events that leads to her tragic demise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: A Far-Right Terrorism Suspect With a Refugee Disguise: The Tale of Franco A.
description: A German officer is facing trial on terrorism charges. At a volatile time for Western democracy, his story mirrors the story of Germany itself.
content: OFFENBACH, Germany — At the height of Europe’s migrant crisis, a bearded man in sweatpants walked into a police station. His pockets were empty except for an old cellphone and a few foreign coins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Scott Donaldson, Biographer of Literary Titans, Dies at 92
description: His subjects included Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Cheever, though he acknowledged that writing a definitive biography was an unattainable goal.
content: Scott Donaldson, a biographer who specialized in literary giants, among them Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and John Cheever, although he called the task of capturing such personages between the covers of a book “the impossible craft,” died on Dec. 1 at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo and Selam Gebrekidan
title: South Africa will make plenty of vaccine. But its citizens are at the back of the line.
description: Over the past few months, rich nations like the United States and Britain have cut deals with multiple drug manufacturers and secured enough doses of coronavirus vaccine to inoculate their citizens many times over. China and Russia have conducted their own trials and begun mass vaccination programs.
content: Over the past few months, rich nations like the United States and Britain have cut deals with multiple drug manufacturers and secured enough doses of coronavirus vaccine to inoculate their citizens many times over. China and Russia have conducted their own trials and begun mass vaccination programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Louisville Officer Who Shot Breonna Taylor Will Be Fired
description: Detective Myles Cosgrove will be terminated along with Detective Joshua Jaynes, who was involved in planning the deadly raid.
content: The Louisville police officer who fired the shot that killed Breonna Taylor, a Black emergency room technician whose death set off a wave of protests on American streets, was told on Tuesday that the department was moving to oust him from the force, as was a second officer who obtained a judge’s approval for the poorly planned nighttime raid on her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: U.K. Says It Can’t Guarantee Assistance for Citizen Held in Iran
description: Britain’s stance on the case of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who awaits trial in Tehran, has drawn criticism as it weighs its international role outside the European Union.
content: The British Foreign Office has said it is not legally obligated to provide assistance to a British-Iranian woman held in Iran since 2016, a position that raises questions about how much protection a Western power is willing to offer its citizens at risk, and what Britain’s international role should be after its exit from the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: With Remote Learning, a 12-Year-Old Knows Her English Is Slipping Away
description: In New York City, 142,000 children are learning English in school. Online classes are especially challenging for them.
content: When Taniya Ria moved to the Bronx from Bangladesh in 2019, she didn’t know a word of English. Within months, Taniya, now 12, was translating for her mother, making American friends in class and getting good grades. Then the pandemic arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Bryan Pietsch
title: First U.S. Case of Highly Contagious Coronavirus Variant Is Found in Colorado
description: The fact that the infected man had no travel history raises the worrisome possibility that the variant is already well established in his community — and perhaps elsewhere in the United States.
content: The first United States case of the more contagious coronavirus variant that was initially discovered in Britain was found in Colorado on Tuesday, Gov. Jared Polis said, raising the worrisome possibility that the variant is already well established in the patient’s community — and perhaps elsewhere.“It didn’t teleport across the Atlantic,” said William Hanage, an epidemiologist at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The Album Steve Earle Never Wanted to Make: A Tribute to His Son
description: Less than two months after Justin Townes Earle’s death from an accidental overdose, his father entered Electric Lady Studios to record an LP’s worth of his songs.
content: On the evening of Aug. 20, Steve Earle spoke to his son Justin Townes Earle for the last time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Branch
title: A Home That Makes Time Travelers of Its Inhabitants
description: In New York’s Catskills region, an old stone house has received a modern upgrade, but retains the thick stone walls that have stood for over two centuries.
content: On a summer afternoon in 2017, a couple on a weekend trip from Manhattan were getting their car serviced at an auto shop in Callicoon, N.Y., a small town in the Catskills. To pass the time, they decided to wander up a nearby hill. At its top, they happened upon an old fieldstone house with robin’s egg blue shutters, a covered porch and an ancient-looking sycamore shading its back lawn. They were so charmed by its storybook appeal that they knocked on the front door. And though it wasn’t officially on the market, its owner, whose family had lived in the home for generations, was in turn so charmed by the couple’s enthusiasm and personal connection to the area (the paternal grandfather and father of one of the visitors were both born nearby) that she sold them the property — the 1,500-square-foot house, together with a large wooden barn and four-and-a-half acres of rolling farmland — just a few months later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Stimulus Checks, Virus Variant, Breonna Taylor: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Xilonen, From the Oxomoco Team, Opens in Greenpoint, Brooklyn
description: A stretch of outdoor dining in Harlem, wine delivery from Baldor, and more restaurant news.
content: The name of this new place, the work of the chef Justin Bazdarich and Chris Walton of Oxomoco nearby, honors the Aztec goddess of young maize. They have put Alan Delgado in charge of the new kitchen, where the food is vegetarian and mostly vegan. Mr. Delgado, who is from Texas and worked there for many years, recently became involved in recipe development for Oxomoco before taking on this position. Some of his specialties for breakfast and lunch, the only meals being served for now in the restaurant’s elaborate outdoor dining area, are a masa pancake with maple syrup and salted butter; braised carrot tostada with navy beans, carrot top salsa verde and spiced maple; and churros with Oaxacan chocolate. (They’re also available for takeout and delivery.) The corn used here and at Oxomoco comes from Tamoa, a Mexican organization that connects farmers growing heritage crops with restaurants in Mexico and the United States. The restaurant has a vibrant mural covering its facade; when dining indoors is permitted, customers will see a room decorated with desert plants and hand-woven textiles in purple, yellow and orange that echo the colors of corn.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 29, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 29, 2020.
content: An article on Saturday about unemployment in the arts misstated one of the performers in the Local Honeys. She is Montana Hobbs, not Monica Hobbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Family of Four and a Home Office, in 660 Square Feet?
description: For one couple looking for a place in Brooklyn, natural light mattered more than space. They knew they’d make the compact apartment work.
content: Most New Yorkers hunting for an apartment to renovate put square footage at the top of their wish lists. Kurt Arnold and Aya Maceda prioritized something else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ted DeLaney, Conscience of a Roiled University, Dies at 77
description: He worked his way up from custodian to department head at Washington and Lee, then a led a reckoning with the Confederate general its very name honored, Robert E. Lee.
content: Ted DeLaney, who began his nearly 60-year career at Washington and Lee University as a custodian, accumulated enough credits to graduate at 41, returned a decade later as a history professor, became the school’s first Black department head and later helped lead its reckoning with the Confederate general its very name honored, Robert E. Lee, died on Dec. 18 at his home in Lexington, Va. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
title: Pompeo Weighs Plan to Place Cuba on U.S. Terrorism Sponsor List
description: The move would complicate any effort by the incoming Biden administration to resume President Barack Obama’s thaw in relations with Havana.
content: State Department officials have drawn up a proposal to designate Cuba as a state sponsor of terrorism, a final-hour foreign policy move that would complicate plans by the incoming Biden administration to relax increased American pressure on Havana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Train for Team Sports Alone
description: Focus on what you can do solo. Find someone to talk to. Seek camaraderie.
content: “You have to find intrinsic motivation,” says Kyra Christmas, 23, who plays on Canada’s national water polo team. Last spring, Christmas and her teammates were living in Montreal, spending up to five hours a day in the pool, training for the 2020 Summer Olympic Games. In mid-March, they got a week off. That same week, Covid-19 forced emergency lockdowns across the country. Pools closed. Team members found themselves hundreds, sometimes thousands, of miles from one another, for what turned into months. Solo athletes know how to push themselves, but for Christmas, who started playing water polo when she was 7, motivation was inextricably tangled up with the sense of being part of something bigger. “It’s hard to be by yourself,” she says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper
title: Cryptocurrency Start-Up Underpaid Women and Black Employees, Data Shows
description: An analysis of internal pay data at the San Francisco company Coinbase shows disparities that were much larger than those in the tech industry.
content: The fast-growing cryptocurrency start-up Coinbase has been rattled in recent months by tensions between executives and employees who said they were being treated unfairly because of their race or gender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Pierre Cardin, Designer to the Famous and Merchant to the Masses, Dies at 98
description: In a career spanning more than three-quarters of a century, he remained a futurist, reproducing fashions for ready-to-wear consumption and affixing his brand to an outpouring of products.
content: Pierre Cardin, the visionary designer who clothed the elite but also transformed the business of fashion, reaching the masses by affixing his name to an outpouring of merchandise ranging from off-the-rack apparel to bath towels, died on Tuesday in Neuilly-sur-Seine, just outside Paris. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wanda Coleman and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: American Sonnet 18
description: Wanda Coleman’s work has jazz, soul and idiosyncrasy.
content: Wanda Coleman’s work has that ineffable quality that accompanies poetry you understand in your belly and your head. And so when she says, “my delicious dilemma is language,” it makes all the sense in the world that she would invent her own American sonnet, a riff on the old song that allows the improvisation and stricture needed to get to this “place where all the lives/are planted in my eyes.” This poem, from her new book of selected works, “Wicked Enchantment,” is classic Coleman: You get the jazz, the soul and also the idiosyncrasy. It is an unmistakable style that propels a Coleman poem, and draws us into it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Jamie McGee, Edmund Lee and Steve Cavendish
title: When Nashville Bombing Hit a Telecom Hub, the Ripples Reached Far Beyond
description: Investigators are questioning whether the perpetrator specifically targeted the building. The explosion disrupted 911 call centers, hospitals and cell service in several states.
content: NASHVILLE — On Christmas morning, emergency officials in the small Alabama town of Cullman found themselves nearly cut off from the outside world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Moscow Turndown
description: Matthew Trout tells a very short story in his New York Times debut, and we can color in the details as we like.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Please welcome Matthew Trout, who is making his crossword debut in The New York Times. In fact, this is Mr. Trout’s first published puzzle, period. Some constructors have a submission chosen by The Times — if they have one chosen at all — only after dozens of rejections. That was not the case for Mr. Trout, a Washington lawyer, so perhaps we’ll be seeing his byline more often. For this Tuesday puzzle, he delivers a relatively quick solve with only a few stumbling blocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
title: The retail industry’s tumultuous year began before the pandemic.
description: The retail industry was in the midst of a transformation before 2020. But the pandemic accelerated that change, fundamentally reordering how and where people shop, and rippling across the broader economy.
content: The retail industry was in the midst of a transformation before 2020. But the pandemic accelerated that change, fundamentally reordering how and where people shop, and rippling across the broader economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Joe Biden Takes Climate Change Seriously
description: His administration’s staffing shows how seriously the incoming president takes this issue.
content: As President-elect Joe Biden rolls out his climate and environment team, it is worth recalling, if only to grasp the distance between then and now, the hopeless bunch President-elect Donald Trump presented us with four years ago. Mr. Trump tapped Scott Pruitt to run the Environmental Protection Agency, Ryan Zinke the Interior Department and Rick Perry the Energy Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Aubry Kaplan
title: In a Miserable Year, I Had the Dodgers and a Stray Dog
description: I mourned my father, democracy and happiness. But there were wins, too.
content: LOS ANGELES — One of the unqualified bright spots of 2020 was the Dodgers winning the World Series after a 32-year drought. Weeks before that, the Lakers took the world championship and made Los Angeles a double winner. It was the first time that has happened since 1988.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Carl Zimmer
title: The first confirmed U.S. case of the more contagious British variant has been found in Colorado.
description: A case of the more contagious coronavirus variant first discovered in Britain was found in Colorado on Tuesday, Gov. Jared Polis said. It is the first confirmed case of the variant in the United States.
content: A case of the more contagious coronavirus variant first discovered in Britain was found in Colorado on Tuesday, Gov. Jared Polis said. It is the first confirmed case of the variant in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: A Farm Family’s Business Caved In. Then the Neighbors Showed Up.
description: Farmers Ralph and Lisa Turner of Freeport, Maine, made a living supplying restaurants. This spring, they had tens of thousands of pounds of crops — and no customers.
content: Farmers Ralph and Lisa Turner of Freeport, Maine, made a living supplying restaurants. This spring, they had tens of thousands of pounds of crops — and no customers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: This Year’s Standout Moments in the Arts
description: Though museums, theaters and galleries were closed, and concerts and festivals canceled, many artists continued creating indelible work.
content: Though museums, theaters and galleries were closed, and concerts and festivals canceled, many artists continued creating indelible work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriella Angotti-Jones
title: With Virus Surging, Ambulance Workers’ Hard Job Just Got Harder
description: Emergency medical technicians play a key role in treating the coronavirus. The latest surge in California has put a strain on these already grueling jobs.
content: Emergency medical technicians play a key role in treating the coronavirus. The latest surge in California has put a strain on these already grueling jobs.

title: A ‘Generous’ Home, in 660 Square Feet
description: For one couple looking for a place in Brooklyn, natural light mattered more than space. They knew they’d make the compact apartment work.
content: For one couple looking for a place in Brooklyn, natural light mattered more than space. They knew they’d make the compact apartment work.

author: By Reuters
title: ‘That Was Easy’: Harris Receives Covid-19 Vaccine
description: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris received the Moderna Covid-19 vaccination on Tuesday at United Medical Center in southeast Washington, and urged the public to get vaccinated as well.
content: Vice President-elect Kamala Harris received the Moderna Covid-19 vaccination on Tuesday at United Medical Center in southeast Washington, and urged the public to get vaccinated as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: McConnell Blocks Vote on $2,000 Stimulus Checks
description: After Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, tried to force an immediate vote on increasing the size of the stimulus checks, Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, blocked the measure, leaving its fate unclear.
content: After Senator Chuck Schumer, the minority leader, tried to force an immediate vote on increasing the size of the stimulus checks, Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, blocked the measure, leaving its fate unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Biden Criticizes Coronavirus Vaccine Distribution
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday criticized the Trump administration’s speed in distributing the coronavirus vaccine, and promised that once in office, he would increase the pace of distribution.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday criticized the Trump administration’s speed in distributing the coronavirus vaccine, and promised that once in office, he would increase the pace of distribution.
